title: Commission on Private Philanthropy and Public Needs
display_string: Commission on Private Philanthropy and Public Needs, 1973-1978

subnotes.content: This series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

The Commission on Private Philanthropy and Public Needs (also known as the Filer Commission) was a 32-member panel formed in November 1973 to obtain information, analysis, and opinions on the function of private philanthropy in American society and its relationship to government. The Commission was established through the initiative of John D. Rockefeller 3rd with the support and encouragement of House Ways and Means chairman Wilbur Mills; Treasury Secretary William Simon; and former Treasury Secretary George Schultz. The chairman of the Commission was John H. Filer, chairman of Aetna Life & Casualty Company. Aetna, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, and the Ford Foundation each contributed $25,000 to get the Commission started. Eventually the Commission raised over $2 million to fund its efforts. The Filer Commission sponsored numerous research studies by scholars in disciplines such as health, education, religion, law, and sociology. This series contains correspondence between members of the Council and the Commission, as well as drafts of the Council's report and recommendations to the Commission; copies of a number of Commission-sponsored studies; and a summary of the Commission's final published report. (Both the final report, "Giving in America: Toward a Stronger Voluntary Sector," and the five-volume "Research Papers" published by the Department of the Treasury are available in the Archive Center library.)
